title: How does the form of 'song of myself' help the poem communicate its theme? - Quora

response.answer_text: Whitman quietly, cleverly conveys the idea that the theme in “Song of Myself” is a self which is “not contained between my hat and boots.” He is hymning the Cosmic Self, the total life force or life process (an evolutionary one - he pictures his soon-to-be-born animal ancestor carried around as an egg in a dinosaur’s mouth). And since the cosmic self is worthy of reverence, he writes the “Song” in 52 parts. This will suggest that you can devote each Sunday morning (or Thursday or Friday evening - whenever you might prefer to say weekly prayers) to reciting or “singing” a section from his year-long scripture-like book of weekly hymns. It’s as good as going to church or mosque or temple, if not maybe a whole lot better! Leaves of Grass grew to be Whitman’s new Bible. His bravery, I think, should not be underestimated.

I won’t do your homework for you. If you want more information on the poem, search for some of the many analyses online. If you are looking for a way to dig into the question, consider (1) What is the theme of the poem? (2) What is the form? (3) What was your reaction to the poem, and can you tease out why your reacted this way. If you can’t figure out how to tie theme and form together, consider asking your teacher. You will learn far more by laying out what you find confusing that you would by reaching for someone else’s answer. Poetry is very personal, and your interpretation and your feelings about the poem are JUST as valid as anyone else’s.
